Allot of people are fully against bringing additional species over to battle invasive pests. Citing Kane Toads as an example.

I would say it depends on how specialized the species is. Kane toads are a huge problem because they are opportunistic predators. Yeah, they’ll eat your pests, but they’ll eat basically any creature that can fit into its mouth and reproduce as long as it can eat. Leading to explosions in toad population and destruction of harmless species who are capable of being eaten.

Parasitic Wasps are a perfect example of targeted pest control. Many species are specifically specialized to parasitize one species of insect or plant. Therefor populations rise and fall with the population of the pest and effectively control the problem.

From reading the comments below, I guess you all think this is some kind of big joke. Intentionally introducing non-indigenous species is a very dangerous thing to do. Nature is very complex. It could, and often does, take unexpected turns, and you can create a problem that was way worse than the one you started out with. Look at Australia introducing the African cane toad. That got totally out of control. Sure those samurai wasps feed on stinkbugs eggs in Japan. But, what if they decide to feed on something else when they get here, let’s say, Honeybee larvae. Oops, no pollinators equals a catastrophic loss of crops. Not good. Now, I’m not an expert and I’m not saying don’t introduce them, but just look at some of the fiascoes that have happened in Florida for example. Just look up “invasive species.“ Just sayin’.

So, I went downstairs and got our bug zapper to fry it myself. I was able to get it onto the rim of the zapper but not onto the wires.

So I was finally like. Well I don't know what kind of bug this is. But I guess it's time to test my reflexes. I got a bunch of tissues and grabbed that sucker and squished it and threw it in my garbage can.

As an Australian, nothing makes me more uncomfortable than the idea of releasing invasive animals to deal with another invasive animal. Helloooo cane toad. In their natural range they feast primarily on cane beetles, just as this wasp does with stink bugs. They figured well, cane beetles are a problem here, let's release the toads. No harm done. Except the toads decided that native animals were a much tastier snack and pretty much ignore the cane beetles. They're now one of Australia's most well known invasive pests. They are a SERIOUS issue pretty much all the way along the north coast. Not only are there no natural predators (aside from humans out specifically to kill them) to control the population, they eat and harm a lot of native wildlife, and are also very dangerous for pet dogs and cats.


I'm glad at least that there's lots of research being done here. The cane toad debacle was in Ye Olde days where people brought anything and everything to Australia without a care. At least there's effort being put in here to make sure it's safe. Even so, it should be last resort imo. You NEVER know how introduction of an invasive species is gonna go until they're actually out in the world. It doesn't matter how much research you do.
